awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  A customizable handheld bioprinter for the in situ deposition of self-healing and polymer-based hydrogels
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a surgical tool for delivery of soft implants and biomaterials into wound sites and desired organs.  Current approaches are limited by the design of the biomaterial that results in inadequate stiffness and low adhesion to host tissue and injections from a needle that are inadequate for large voids, such as surgically-resected tumor regions.  The proposed technology allows easy, rapid and more controlled delivery of multi-component biomaterials for tissue reconstruction surgery. It may minimize operative risks involved during complex procedures, reduce susceptibility to infection, and decrease the duration of anesthesia exposure. It may be translated into other clinical applications by providing a rapid delivery of functional implants for all reconstruction surgeries. 

This I-Corps project will advance translation of a customizable handheld bioprinter, which allows for the in situ deposition of self-healing and polymer-based hydrogels to fabricate stable and functional tissue implants. Such hydrogels are based on guest–host physical interactions of a macrocyclic host and a complementary guest molecule. In addition, the proposed technology uses UV crosslinking of methacrylate groups in the hydrogel for long-term stability of the implant.  The device is an additive manufacturing tool based on a custom-made, endoscopic-sized, handheld bioprinter.  This device provides simultaneous extrusion of biomaterials into multi-layered concentric layers of blunt needles where the needle lengths are selected to control movement and dispensing over the structure bioprinted. Advantages of this technology include a modular mixing chamber for blending of multi-component biomaterials, a flexible, ergonomic handle that may be adopted to surgical robots/tools, a significant level of control over deposition of multi-component biomaterials over tissue sites, and a high-aspect ratio for hard-to-reach organs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.inst_street_address: 323 DR MARTIN LUTHER KING JR BLVD

por.por_cntn:
The global three-dimensional (3D) printing healthcare market size was valued at $973 million in 2018 and is projected to reach $3.7 billion by 2026, growing at a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 18.2% from 2019 to 2026. This market continues to grow aggressively because bioprinting provides several advantages over traditional reconstructive surgeries by reducing the operative risks involved during complex procedures, minimizes susceptibility to infection, and decreases the duration of anesthesia exposure. This would enable patients to recover faster and reduce the duration of hospital stay. With this knowledge and performing over ~120 interviews with surgeons and medical practitioners, the team has found that the current standard procedures of tissue implantation include tedious preparation steps and post-implantation processes. The biomaterials are commonly placed by direct injections onto tissue sites or filling spaces. The current standard procedures include biomaterials preparation steps and require post-implantation processes, such as in vivo curing and wound dressing. They operate only for a single biomaterial, so they are used in subsequent procedures.  The successful development of in situ platforms will represent a paradigm shift in the biomedical community by improving patients’ quality of life and opening radical engineering tools in reconstructive surgeries. A possible solution would be to deposit multiple biomaterial precursors while allowing real-time mixing during the deposition period, rather than relying on premixing processes. Key research findings and technologies have been communicated to the broader community via conferences and scientific meetings. The project also resulted in the interdisciplinary and collaborative training of undergraduate students in science, engineering, and management (Rowan University and NJIT).


Last Modified: 07/05/2022
Modified by: Amir K Miri
